A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,

PIONEER EXPERIENCES; A GENEAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: Cayford Guy H.
2. Your address: Neikburg, Sask.
3. Date: Oct. 10th, 1962.
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Minnesota, U.S.A.
5. In what year was your father's name and occupation? Howard H. Cayford.
   He was a farmer, rancher, and a railroad engineer.
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): August 1903.
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: 30 miles away Medicine Hat on the Bow River.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.)
9. What were your reasons for coming West? (If you could not have answered this question had you not been compelled by a few years and the urge a lot of adventure in the U.S.A about the wonderful County west of Manitoba called the North West Territories of Canada, so my Dad took a few land entries off the town of MINEAPOLIS in 1902 & 1904.)
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

With whom we left the River County in 1905:

Joe Went to school by Wagon Train, and our main source of information was taken from a book published in Ottawa called "Down of Canada Surveyors Notes." It gave a good description of the County, the lay of the land, lakes and rivers, and of course, named a river named Palliser.

Palouse Tryangle.

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: 80 miles west of Medicine Hat on the Bow River.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.)
9. What were your reasons for coming West? (What will you find in Canada? From U.S.A. in 1904)
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

With whom did you travel to the New River County in 1905?

To the West to school by Wagon Train, and our main streets information was taken from a book published in Ottawa called "Down to Canada" by Mr. Guy, the top of the land label and discipline of the country, the top of the land label and trees, and of course.

Palmer Tinyangle.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

My Dad and I thought we came up to 50 miles from the town of Delta, BC.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other group)?

Yes, we traveled with my Dad and I.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Wagon and saddle horse.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

We met many people along the way, but we had to be friendly.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

About 12 miles south of Waskamino.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

On the west side of the river.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

No other permanent residence just liquid and Calgary.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

Dad worked on the railroad. He also farmed and homesteaded in Canada.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

My Dad and Mother came via train. We traveled by train.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other group)?

We traveled by train.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Train

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

The trip was very long and tiring. We met many interesting people along the way.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

About 12 miles south of Wadena, Saskatchewan.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

S.W. 1/4 of the 34-49-26 W4

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

About 1 mile from Edmonton, Alberta, and Calgary.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

Dad worked on the railroad. He also farmed and raised cattle.

Little Glen, Mother was a school teacher.

Married, Gloria Mitchell, at Las Huesos.

Yes, we would stay there too.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

We all came to settle there in 1904 and we paid our arrival and then we bought land by 1910.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Our nearest town was 20 miles, but traveled there about once a week, more than a radius of about 40 miles to visit or go to church, actually about 10 miles and we traveled by wagon, buggy or horse back or on foot.

No, not after 1923, when the CPR came in from Wilkie to Lily Lake.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Yes, there were many who moved away.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

No, they moved away.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I was a local post office clerk from 1942 to 1955.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district, mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combining, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

My dad helped to organize the first Melton District, being WELLS School No. 1496 in the year 1906.

NEIL BURGE got the name of Neilson Burge. He had a little store in the spring of 1905; he landed his supplies from Butteville. He called his place NEILBURGE and Selma District was called Mulberry and New Town of Millburg.
5. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1947? What reasons did they have for moving?
